Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Australia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Nikole Nielsen of New Mexico State University to conduct a research project, entitled "Gas properties in interacting galaxies using fingerprints in background quasar light," during the summer of 2012 at Swinburne University of Technology in Melbourne, Australia. The host scientist is Michael Murphy.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to contribute to the quest to understand the evolution of galaxies and provide key insights for understanding isolated galaxies such as the Milky Way and their histories. This is accomplished by studying the gas in galaxies - an important component of baryons in the galactic ecosystem and the fuel from which stars and planets form and evolve - and how it responds to interactions between galaxies. Because all galaxies were interacting galaxies at one point in their history, interacting galaxies provide an excellent astrophysical laboratory to observe cannibalistic events in progress and test current theories of how these events affect galaxies.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation's East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes gave me the opportunity to travel to Australia to work with Dr. Michael Murphy, and Dr. Glenn Kacprzak (both at the Swinburne University of Technology in Hawthorn, Victoria, Australia). We characterized the gaseous halos around galaxies, known as the circumgalactic medium (CGM), using a control sample of isolated galaxies with known MgII absorption. We studied the extent and patchiness of the CGM and how it depends on the luminosity, color, orientation, and mass of the host galaxy. We also studied how the velocities of gas clouds in the CGM depend on the host galaxy properties.

Studying the CGM is central to the broader aspects of astronomical sciences because the modern paradigm of galaxy evolution points to the CGM as the primary astronomical environment governing galaxy evolution. The results from our study present a useful test for theoretical predictions of the accretion of gas onto and outflowing gas from galaxies, which are key processes in galaxy evolution, and how they depend on the properties of the host galaxy.

To conduct our characterization, we developed a standardized catalog of galaxies associated with MgII absorption fingerprints in background quasar light from the literature. This is the largest database of its kind and allows for detailed analysis of the MgII circumgalactic medium.

With this unique sample, we found that more luminous, more massive galaxies tend to have more MgII gas at a given distance from the host galaxy, and that this gas extends further for these galaxies than for less luminous, less massive galaxies. The CGM in lower luminosity, lower mass galaxies tends to be more patchy than in higher luminosity, higher mass galaxies. If we take into account that more massive galaxies are larger, while less massive galaxies are smaller, we find no difference in the amount and distribution of gas. These results all
indicate that the mass of galaxies (which is related to luminosity) governs the amount of gas and its extent around galaxies more than any other galaxy property.

We also found that halo gas has a preference in where it is distributed around the host galaxy - halo gas is more likely to be found perpendicular to the disk (gas is ejected from the galaxy above and below the disk due to outflowing winds from star formation) or parallel to the disk (gas is accreted onto the galaxy in the plane of the disk, feeding star formation) of the galaxy, rather than uniformly distributed around the galaxy. We find that bluer galaxies, which are
typically undergoing large amounts of star formation, show this preference, whereas redder galaxies, those that are no longer forming stars, do not. Therefore, bluer galaxies are still growing and changing, whereas redder galaxies are no longer dominated by star formation and are known as "red and dead."

When we studied the spread in the velocities of the gas clouds associated with the MgII absorption, we found that bluer and lower luminosity galaxies have larger velocity spreads than redder and higher luminosity galaxies. This result, as above, may be indicative of the large amounts of inflowing and outflowing gas in bluer, less luminous galaxies, whereas the redder, more luminous galaxies are passive.

These results all indicate that the CGM is strongly linked to the properties of the host galaxy and that if a galaxy is not actively redistributing its gas (or has no gas), it cannot evolve by way of star formation.
